questions.text: Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) is used to diagnose chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) in a patient presenting chronic fatigue and exertional dyspnea. Which of the following is most likely to be observed with a performance of this test on this patient?

choices.text: Translocation of BCR and ABL genes
DNA rearrangement in the BCR promoter region
Fusion protein containing BCR and ABL domains
Messenger RNA transcript containing BCR and ABL exons
Point mutation in the ABL enhancer region

questions.solution:
Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) allows for the direct localization of genes to their respective chromosomes by using a labeled DNA probe complementary to the sequence of interest. In patients with a genetic translocation, the fluorescence signal corresponding to one chromosome is found in a different chromosome. In the case of patients with CML, this will reflect a translocation of the BCR-ABL genes, also known as the Philadelphia chromosome.  

Option Analysis

✅ Translocation of BCR and ABL genes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ DNA rearrangement in the BCR promoter region  :
Incorrect: Polymerase chain reaction techniques can detect changes in this non transcribed region.  
❌ Fusion protein containing BCR and ABL domains  :
Incorrect: Western Blot studies can detect the BCR-ABL protein using monoclonal antibodies directed against BCR or ABL.  
❌ Messenger RNA transcript containing BCR and ABL exons  :
Incorrect: Reverse transcriptase-PCR can be used to diagnose chronic myelogenous leukemia by identifying an mRNA transcript containing both BCR and ABL exons in affected cells.  
❌ Point mutation in the ABL enhancer region  :
Incorrect: Polymerase chain reaction techniques can detect changes in this non transcribed region.

questions.text:
Using fluorescent DNA probes, an investigator performs a fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) study. The study demonstrates a lack of fluorescence at the 5p region of chromosome 5 compared to fluorescence at the same locus on the second copy of that chromosome, as shown below. Based on the results of this FISH study, which of the following is a possible diagnosis?
 

Reproduced from Journal of Medical Genetics
questions.solution:
Submicroscopic deletions of chromosome 5 (5p15) are detected by fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) in individuals with cri-du-chat syndrome. In patients with this disease, a lack of fluorescence will be observed in one of the 5p regions of chromosome 5 compared to fluorescence at the same locus on the second copy of chromosome 5.  

Option Analysis

❌ Patau syndrome  :
Incorrect: Patau syndrome is an autosomal trisomy of chromosome 13, usually resulting from meiotic nondisjunction. It is generally diagnosed by karyotype analysis which shows Trisomy 13.  
❌ Down syndrome:
Incorrect: Down syndrome is an autosomal trisomy of chromosome 13, usually resulting from meiotic nondisjunction. It is generally diagnosed by karyotype analysis which shows Trisomy 21.  
❌ Edward syndrome:
Incorrect: Edward syndrome is an autosomal trisomy of chromosome 18, usually resulting from meiotic nondisjunction. It is diagnosed by karyotype analysis which shows Trisomy 18.  
❌ Fragile X syndrome  :
Incorrect: Fragile X syndrome is an X-linked disorder that demonstrates discontinuity with staining of the left arm of the X chromosome.  
✅ Cri du chat:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A group of investigators studying molecular cloning insert a target gene into a circular piece of DNA called a plasmid. Which of the following best describes the purpose of molecular cloning?

choices.text: Localization of genes and direct visualization of chromosomal anomalies at the molecular level
Production of a recombinant DNA molecule in a bacterial host
Detect the presence of a specific antigen or antibody in serum
Assess size, granularity, and protein expression of cells in a sample

questions.solution:
Molecular cloning refers to the experimental production of recombinant DNA molecules within host organisms (e.g. bacterial hosts). This process involves:
 
  1.  Isolation of eukaryotic target mRNA 
  2.  Production of complementary DNA (cDNA) using reverse transcriptase 
  3.  Insertion of cDNA fragments into a cloning vector (e.g., bacterial plasmids carrying the antibiotic resistance genes) 
  4.  Transformation of the produced recombinant plasmid into bacteria 
  5.  Selection of bacteria that contains the plasmid (e.g., via antibiotic exposure when cloning antibiotic resistance genes) 
The end result is the synthesis of multiple copies of the target cDNA (cloned DNA).  

Option Analysis

❌ Localization of genes and direct visualization of chromosomal anomalies at the molecular level  :
Incorrect: Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) is used for specific localization of genes and direct visualization of chromosomal anomalies at the molecular level.  
✅ Production of a recombinant DNA molecule in a bacterial host  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Diagnose chromosomal imbalance:
Incorrect: With karyotyping, chromosomes are stained, ordered, and numbered according to morphology, size, arm-length ratio, and banding pattern. This technique is used to diagnose chromosomal imbalances such as autosomal trisomies.  
❌ Detect the presence of a specific antigen or antibody in serum:
Incorrect: Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) is an immunologic test used to detect the presence of either a specific antigen or antibody in a patient’s blood sample. Detection involves the use of an antibody linked to an enzyme.  
❌ Assess size, granularity, and protein expression of cells in a sample  :
Incorrect: Flow cytometry is a laboratory technique that assesses the size, granularity, and protein expression (immunophenotype) of individual cells in a sample. It is commonly used in the workup of hematologic abnormalities and immunodeficiencies.
